titleStmt.title: Active Disturbance Rejection Control Approach to Output-Feedback Stabilization of a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems Subject to Stochastic Disturbance

analytic.title: Active Disturbance Rejection Control Approach to Output-Feedback Stabilization of a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems Subject to Stochastic Disturbance

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TAC.2015.2471815, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) is now considered as a powerful control strategy in dealing with large uncertainty covering unknown dynamics, external disturbance, and unknown part in coefficient of the control. However, all theoretical works up to present are limited to deterministic uncertainty. In this paper, we generalize the ADRC to uncertain nonlinear systems subject to external bounded stochastic disturbance described by an uncertain stochastic differential equation driven by white noise. We first design an extended state observer (ESO) that is used to estimate both state, and total disturbance which includes the internal uncertain nonlinear part and the external uncertain stochastic disturbance. It is shown that the resulting closed-loop system is asymptotically stable in the mean-square topology. The numerical experiments are carried out to illustrate effectiveness of the proposed approach.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: The idea of active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) initiated by Han [5] has been attracting more attention by the industry practitioners as presented in latest survey-type paper [3]. The numerous concrete applications in different fields include control of flexible joint manipulator [12], control of a model-scale helicopter [10], control of omnidirectional mobile robot [14], control of synchronous motors [15], and control of delta parallel robot [13].

On the other hand, the progress has also been made in theoretical foundations, see [4], [17]. In addition, the ADRC has been successfully applied to stabilization for systems described by partial differential equations. However, in these works, the external disturbance is always assumed to be deterministic. This is not very realistic because many real control systems are most often subject to the influence of randomness, which is a source of instability of the control systems. Actually, output-feedback stabilization for stochastic nonlinear systems driven by white noise has been receiving increasing attention in last two decades. By employing a quartic Lyapunov function, the paper [1] presents a backstepping design to achieve a first result on global output-feedback stabilization for stochastic nonlinear systems. A problem of stochastic disturbance attenuation is discussed in [2] for the systems driven by white noise of unknown covariance. Several different output-feedback controllers are developed for stochastic nonlinear systems with unmeasured states, such as tracking control [8] and decentralized control [11]. However, in these studies, the system functions are supposed to be known or the system uncertainties are linearly parameterized with respect to known nonlinear functions. To overcome this obstacle, outputfeedback control approaches such as adaptive neural network [9] are investigated for uncertain stochastic systems with unmeasured states.

However, much less results are available on output-feedback stabilization problem for stochastic nonlinear systems with both uncertain system functions and stochastic non-white exogenous disturbance. In this paper, we consider a class of nonlinear systems disturbed by some bounded "colored noise" which satisfies an uncertain Itô-type stochastic differential equation. Actually, such kind of exogenous disturbance exists in many practical dynamical systems. A typical example is the stochastic nonlinear reactor systems, in which the external reactivity noise may be more realistic to be assumed to be non-white because of various noise mechanisms and time constants involved in the various feedback paths. But the fundamental noise sources that bring about the reactivity noise through various feedback mechanisms may be regarded as white, i.e., the external reactivity noise can be produced by passing the white noise through a filter, described by an Itô-type stochastic differential equation [16]. This motivates us to consider the ADRC approach to the uncertain nonlinear systems with bounded uncertain non-white stochastic disturbance. In contrast to most of the available results, the main contributions of this paper lie in: an extended state observer (ESO) is designed, for the first time, not only to estimate the unmeasured states, but also the internal uncertain nonlinear part and the bounded external uncertain stochastic disturbance, and an ESO-based output-feedback control is designed to stabilize the system. In addition, most of the available output-feedback controllers are used to guarantee the global asymptotic stability in probability [1] for the case where the noise vector field is vanishing at the origin or the noise-to-state (or input-tostate) stability in probability [2] [8] otherwise. In this paper however, we address a kind of asymptotic stability for the stochastic nonlinear systems with nonvanishing noise vector field. Precisely, we consider the following uncertain stochastic nonlinear system:
where

are the state, the control (input), and the output (measurement) of system, respectively. f, ϕ : [0, ∞) × R n → R are possibly unknown measurable system functions, w(t) ∈ R is the uncertain external disturbance which is assumed to satisfy an Itô-type stochastic differential equation as follows:
div.formula: dw(t) = φ(t, w(t))dt + ψ(t, w(t))dBt, w(0) = w0, (2
div.p: where {Bt} t≥0 is a one-dimensional standard Brownian motion defined on a complete probability space (Ω, F , {Ft} t≥0 , P ) with a natural filtration {Ft} t≥0 (i.e. Ft = σ{Bs, 0 ≤ s ≤ t}), and unknown F0-measurable initial value w0 which is independent of the σ-algebra generated by Bt(•), t ≥ 0. The functions φ, ψ : [0, ∞) × R → R are possibly unknown measurable functions. We proceed as follows. In the next section, Section 2, we design a nonlinear extended state observer to estimate both state and total disturbance, the most original feature of the ADRC approach compared with other approaches aforementioned. The mean-square convergence is proved under additional assumptions. As a direct consequence, we conclude the convergence of linear extended state observer. Section 3 is devoted to asymptotic mean-square convergence for the closedloop system. The convergence of closed-loop system under the linear extended state observer based feedback is also concluded. In Section 4, some numerical experiments for a physical motivated example are carried out to illustrate effectiveness of the proposed approach.

div.head: II. EXTENDED STATE OBSERVER
div.p: For a given vector X ∈ R n , we use X to denote its transpose, and X the Euclidean norm. The Assumption (H1) is a prior assumption about the unknown functions f (•), ϕ(•), φ(•), ψ(•), and control u(t).
Assumption (H1). The possibly unknown functions f (•) and ϕ(•) are continuously differentiable with respect to their variables, and there exist (known) constants ci > 0, i = 0, 1
Motivated by [4] for deterministic systems, we design a nonlinear extended state observer (NLESO in shorthand) for system (1) as follows:

div.p: Notice that the solution of (6) depends on parameter ε but we drop ε by abuse of notation without confusion.
The following Assumption (H2) is a prior assumption about the solutions of (1) and the external stochastic disturbance w(t).

div.head: Assumption (H2). There exists a (known

Remark II.1. Compared with the deterministic case, we can see from the proof of Theorem II.1 that since the total disturbance contains the stochastic term, the Itô differential of the total disturbance has diffusion term. So the Itô differential of the Lyapunov function for the error equation contains not only the gradient, but also the higher order Hessian term. This makes the estimation for total disturbance much more difficult than for the deterministic case.
The simplest ESO is the linear extended state observer (LESO) that is a special case of (6):
div.formula:                dx1(t) = x2(t)dt + a 1 ε (y(t) -x1(t))dt, . . . dxn(t) = xn+1(t)dt + an ε n (y(t) -x1(t))dt + u(t)dt, dxn+1(t) = a n+1 ε n+1 (y(t) -x1(t))dt,(18)
div.p: where ai, i = 1, 2, ..., n + 1 are chosen so that the following matrix is Hurwitz:
Corollary II.1. Under Assumptions (H1)-(H2), the linear extended state observer (18) is convergent in the sense that for any initial values x0 ∈ R n+1 , x0 ∈ R n+1 and any T > 0,

div.p: where λmax(P ) and λmin(P ) are the maximal and minimal eigenvalues of P , respectively. So V (η) and W (η) satisfy Assumption (H3). The result then follows from Theorem II.1.

div.head: III. ESO BASED OUTPUT FEEDBACK
div.p: The next step is to design an ESO-based feedback control. First, we notice that when there is no total disturbance, the following state feedback control:
where k1, k2, ..., kn are constants to be chosen so that the matrix following
is Hurwitz can stabilize system (1). Since we have obtained estimations for all states and total disturbance claimed by Theorem II.1, an ESO-based output feedback control is naturally designed as

where the last term xn+1(t) is obviously used to compensate the effect of the total disturbance f + ϕ • w because of xn+1 ≈ f + ϕ • w. This is just the estimation/cancellation nature of ADRC. Like Corollary II.1, under the LESO (18) based feedback control (22), we have immediately the Corollary III.1.

Corollary III.1. Under Assumptions (H1) and (ii) of (H2), for any initial values x0 ∈ R n+1 , x0 ∈ R n+1 , the closed-loop system of ( 1), (18), and ( 22) admits a solution and is asymptotically stable in the sense that :

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS
div.p: In this section, we present some numerical simulations on stabilization for a linear harmonic oscillator subject to external bounded stochastic disturbance presented in [7], which is described by the following equation:

where α is the frequency of degenerated linear oscillator, β is the coefficient of linear damping, h is the amplitude of bounded noise, w(t) is the bounded external stochastic disturbance that contains the parameter noise and the influence of a random environment. For this oscillator, the total energy is ( [7])
As pointed out in [7], the bounded stochastic disturbance w(t) of the oscillator can be of the form:

where λ and ξ 2 are constants representing center frequency and strength of frequency perturbation, respectively, and ν is random phase uniformly distributed in [0, 2π]. Here we consider the case of ν = 0 for simplicity. In this case, it is easy to compute by Itô's formula that w(t) is a bounded disturbance which satisfies an Itô-type stochastic differential equation where the corresponding functions φ(•), ψ(•) in (2) satisfy the condition (5). Set
Then the control system of the motion of the oscillator (31) with the input (control) u(t) and the output (measurement) y(t) = x(t) can be rewritten as follows:

We design a NLESO (6) for system (35) as
where ϕ(•) : R → R is defined as

Similar to [4], Assumption (H3) in ( 7) is satisfied for this example. Hence (36) serves as a well-defined NLESO for (35) from Theorem II.1. For numerical computations, the Milstein approximation method [6] is used to discretize systems (35) and (36). Figure1 and Figure 2 display the numerical results for (35) and (36) where we take
and the initial values are taken as
For the open-loop system, we suppose without loss of generality that the bounded input u(t) is also disturbed by a stochastic noise:
It is seen from Figure 1 that the NLESO (36) is very effective in tracking the system (35) not only for the state (x1(t), x2(t)) but also for the extended state (total disturbance) x3(t) defined by
For the closed-loop system, the NLESO based feedback control is designed as follows:
The maximal real part of the eigenvalues of matrix
is -1. From Theorem III.1, we know that the closed-loop system is asymptotically stable under the output feedback control (41) in the sense that lim t→∞ ε→0

In addition, Figure 2 shows the stability of each component of the trajectory (x1(t), x2(t)). This is because (43) implies almost sure convergence of each xi(t), i = 1, 2. The peaking values are observed in both Figure 1 and Figure 2, which can be overcome by timevarying gain approach presented in recent paper [17].

div.head: V. CONCLUDING REMARKS
div.p: In this paper, the active disturbance rejection (ADRC) is extended to a class of nonlinear systems with large uncertainties that come from both internal unknown dynamics and external stochastic disturbance. The key idea is to use an extended state observer (ESO) to estimate, in real time, not only the state but also the uncertainties, and then compensate uncertainties in the feedback loop. It is shown that the resulting closed-loop system is asymptotically stable in the meansquare topology.

Compared to the deterministic case, the ADRC approach for stochastic nonlinear systems is far from fully understanding. It is found for deterministic systems in [13] and [15] that the ADRC approach can be established based on generalized proportional integral observer (GPI) instead of ESO to deal with more complicated perturbed differentially flat nonlinear systems with measurable flat outputs. It would be interesting to generalize the present result to stochastic counterpart of systems considered in [13] and [15]. (c) Fig. 2. The closed-loop for the state (x 1 (t), x 2 (t)), and total disturbance x 3 (t), and their estimations (x 1 (t), x2 (t)), and x3 (t) under the control u(t) = -2x 1 (t) -3x 2 (t) -x3 (t) by NLESO (36).
